title: Zone 2 Exercise and Training
content: Zone 2 exercise and training was discussed. This was originally recorded as an Instagram Live in March 2021. To learn more about zone 2 training, listen to our episode with a Ph.D. and AMA #19: Deep dive on Zone 2 training, magnesium supplementation, and how to engage with your doctor.

title: Using Rate of Perceived Exertion
content: Ultimately you default into this RPE state, which is once you lose the ability to talk out loud, not whisper, literally have a discussion with somebody on the phone, you’re out a zone 2. If you’re speaking to somebody on the phone or standing next to you with great ease, you’re below zone 2.

title: Reducing Exposure to Gas Stove Emissions
content: Complete elimination of exposure is not practical or possible, but we have many options – such as spot ventilation (range hoods), natural ventilation, and air purifiers – for reducing exposure to excess NO2 attributable to gas stoves without needing to replace the stove entirely. The U.S. EPA’s safety limit for NO2 is 100 parts per billion (ppb), and they estimate that ambient air averages about 53 ppb. Previous work has shown that NO2 levels in homes with gas stoves typically range from 25-75 ppb, or about 15-25 ppb more than homes without gas stoves. According to a study at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory, the most effective strategy is to employ a range hood while cooking. The authors report that use of a range hood eliminated 60-87% of NO2 associated with stove use.

title: Outdoor Exposure to Air Pollution
content: In addition to these strategies for improving air quality in our own homes, we can also take steps to reduce the outdoor exposure and the impact that ambient pollution has on our health. A variety of websites and free apps are available for monitoring outdoor air quality in various cities or regions. Using this information, we can modify our behavior in order to minimize exposure to (and damage from) PM2.5.

title: About the Study
content: The NEJM results are certainly exciting – total elimination of cancer in any patient is worthy of celebration – but when we look more closely, we find that even with a 100% response rate, dostarlimab, like IL-2 therapy, is unlikely to be a universal cancer cure. Only 12 patients have thus far completed the full treatment regimen out of a starting cohort of 16, all of whom had locally-advanced (stage II or III) rectal adenocarcinoma. These cancers all shared the key characteristic of “mismatch repair deficiency,” meaning that they included mutations which impair a cell’s ability to correct mistakes in DNA during replication.

title: Mental and Emotional Health
content: A couple of unrelated events over the past few months have led me to view 2020 as a year to implement some new routines around my mental and emotional health. I read (and then reread) Ryan Holiday’s exceptional book Stillness is the Key. It really resonated, especially the second time, as I was in a place to be more willing to hear the message: no matter how busy or productive we are, and frankly, the busier and more productive we aspire to be, the more we need periods of true stillness. Furthermore, there is no better place to find stillness than in nature. To that end, walking (in nature) with zero agenda—not doing so to “get a workout” or “see something” specific—may be one of the best tools for finding this elusive state.

title: Sleep Hygiene and Better Sleep
content: Sleep hygiene, wind-down routine, and tips for better sleep

title: Sleep Hygiene and Better Sleep
content: Sleep hygiene, wind-down routine, and tips for better sleep

title: Adjusting to New Time Zones
content: Adjusting to a new time zone can be done by slowly adjusting bedtime and wake schedule over the course of 10 days. This helps the internal clock adjust to the new time zone.

title: Sleep Deprivation and Health
content: Under conditions of starvation, animals need to be more alert to search for food. However, this feeling is temporary and sleep debt still accumulates. Mother Nature has never had to face challenge of sleep deprivation, so no biological safety nets exist for any essential functions without sleep. People often think they can accumulate sleep debt during the week and then make it up on the weekend, but this is like sleep bulimia and is torture on circadian biology. There is a whole arsenal of tools in the sleep doc kind of box that we can use, to sort of make these manipulations, either be it for people with insomnia, be it people with anxiety, be it people with jet lag, or what’s called circadian phase delay.

title: Research on LAMZ
content: More needs to be understood about the effects of LAMZ before it is translated to human trials, including its efficacy in elderly populations.

title: Apneic Hypoxemic Index vs Oxygen Desaturation Index
content: The Oxygen Desaturation Index (ODI) with a 4% cutoff is preferred. Mortality data indicates that more than ~25 4% ODIs per hour is a significant predictor of mortality. The Apnea Hypopnea Index looks at the number of times that you have a true apneic event where you have a cessation of breathing. A moderate degree of apnea would be a cessation of breath between 10 to 15 per hour.

title: Impact of Near Tasks on Vision
content: Near tasks such as reading and extended screen time can result in nearsightedness. Things are very well in focus at a typical normal reading distance for someone who has spent a lot of time reading or doing near tasks. This is a result of their development.

title: Minimizing Jet Lag and Sleep Disruption While Traveling
content: To minimize jet lag and sleep disruption while traveling, it is recommended to immediately 'put yourself' in the destination time zone when you leave the place of origin. This can involve sleeping for a certain number of hours on the plane and staying up until a normal bedtime on destination time. It can also involve waking up early and going to bed earlier in the days before the trip, getting exercise, and avoiding caffeine on the day of the trip. Supplements such as phosphatidylserine and sleep remedies can be used to help induce sleep, and modafinil can be used to help stay awake upon arrival.

title: Effects of Technology on Sleep
content: Excessive technology use and exposure to light can negatively impact sleep. We are 'dark deprived' and need darkness to release melatonin. Using an iPad before bed can cause a 50% drop in melatonin, delay the peak melatonin arrival by 3 hours, reduce REM time, and these effects can last 2-3 days. Television usage can make the brain associate the bedroom with TV, which can trigger insomnia and anxiety. Devices can cause sleep procrastination and anticipatory anxiety, which can reduce the amount of deep sleep.

title: Temporal Variations in Blood Flow and Edema
content: What areas have temporal variations in blood flow? Is there edema?

title: Shock Absorption and Aging
content: We absorb shock through the frontal plane of the foot. Being able to absorb shock efficiently is critical as we age.

title: Sleep and Children
content: The sleep needs of children, the travesty of early school start times, electronics at night, and advice for parents.

title: Insights on Alzheimer’s Disease, Cancer, Exercise, Nutrition, and Fasting
content: A scientist with expertise in the areas of aging, cancer, and nutrition translates complex scientific topics into actionable insights. The latest thinking as it relates to Alzheimer's was discussed.

title: Issue #4: Very small numbers of people in the most active group
content: Very small numbers of people in the most active group is an issue. For example, in the Arem paper, there were 31x times less in the active group vs. the moderate group.

title: Final Takeaways on Sleep
content: You have to find the balance between the art and the science on this. Once you’re getting too bent out of shape over it, you’ve gone too far, you’ve got to back off and take the tracker off and stop micromanaging it. At the other end of the spectrum, a lot of people who sleep poorly, it’s really easy to fix if they’re really being brutally honest with their sleep hygiene stuff. Are you really stopping your food and your alcohol or cutting your alcohol all together at the right time? Are you really winding yourself down and not winding yourself up before bed? Are you in a dark room? Is it cool? And are you giving yourself 8.5 hours to be in bed?

title: Recommendations for Better Sleep
content: To get better sleep, limit technology use, especially in the bedroom. Social media in the bedroom can lead to fear of missing out, which can lead to insufficient sleep. If you struggle with sleep, you should read in a different room and go to bed when sleepy. LED light bulbs are more deleterious in terms of suppressing melatonin. Warm red and yellow light is best, though all light will interfere with melatonin. Lower wattage light is best for reading at night.

title: What are the Costs of COVID Policies
content: Anxiety in teens kept at home away from their social network. Pressure of using Zoom. Now that we have better immunity against severe disease, do we need to change our society over COVID. Does every child need to be vaccinated. Policies are damaging our community and society.

title: Cancer Treatment and HIV Case Study
content: At the time Keith was finishing school, AZTs were starting to be used to treat HIV/AIDS successfully. Keith said his talking point was…“we need to find, in cancer, as many ‘AZTs’ as we need, as the initial foot in the door. We know we’re going to receive resistance in this much more complex entity that is a human cell that’s gone rogue, versus relatively simple virus. But it’s when we poke it with the AZT equivalents, we’re going to learn about how it is that it tries to adapt. That’s going to allow us to develop rational combination therapy exactly the way the HIV field does.”

title: Prostate Cancer Research
content: Discusses the most exciting areas of research in prostate cancer.

title: Sleep Supplements
content: Discusses some sleep supplements with remarkable efficacy. Talks about updated thoughts on blue light and a remarkable drug for aiding sleep quality.

title: Potential Solution to Cancer
content: Early detection and prevention—a potential solution to the cancer problem.

title: Preventing cardiovascular disease: diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health
content: Latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more for preventing cardiovascular disease.

title: Immune-based Approaches to Cancer
content: Accomplishing this goal requires treatments of varying degrees of aggressiveness depending on the patient and on the tumor. In very rare instances, the immune system is capable of fighting advanced cancer all on its own, resulting in spontaneous regression without treatment. For others, simply jump-starting the immune system’s natural activity in sufficient: some of the earliest successes in immunotherapy came during the 1980s when melanoma patients were treated with high doses of interleukin-2 (IL-2), a cytokine which plays a key role in immune stimulation by promoting T cell growth and activation.

title: Stoicism and Stillness
content: Obstacle is the Way is particularly well-suited for this moment in time for those who may have been knocked on your ass and you’re trying to figure out ‘what next’? Stillness is the Key is best for those you might be suffering from anxiety, stress, or worry over this and you’re interested in calming your racing mind

title: Sauna and Brain Health
content: Sauna use may have potential brain benefits. However, more research is needed to confirm these benefits and establish a personal protocol.

title: Sleep Strategies
content: Strategies for sleeping more and sleeping better are discussed, including dealing with issues such as sleep apnea and creating an optimal sleep environment.

title: Sleep Compression
content: There is an increasing pressure in modern society to sleep less. With unlimited resources and time, there is a desire to discover a technological way to develop a technique where sleep can be compressed down to four hours, four and a half hours, and it remains just as good as eight hours of sleep.

title: Insights on Alzheimer’s Disease, Cancer, Exercise, Nutrition, and Fasting
content: Scientist with expertise in the areas of aging, cancer, and nutrition who translates complex scientific topics into actionable insights. Latest thinking as it relates to Alzheimer's.

title: Signal-to-Noise in Science
content: Science is about signal-to-noise. You have to be able to predict the noise almost perfectly. It’s critical to understand the standard model predictions of what you would expect to see if there’s nothing new out there and what you would expect to see from the understood flaws of the equipment. Looking at effects in parts per billion or trillion, so must understand the flaws in your detector beyond that level.

title: Effects of Blue Light on Circadian Rhythm
content: Blue light is increasingly present in our environment and can interfere with our circadian clocks. It is important to find ways to mitigate the potential damage caused by excessive exposure to blue light.

title: Healthcare Challenges and Needs
content: The basic tools, technologies, and medicines that could save many lives are lacking. There are logistical challenges in helping the hospital, and what is really needed is discussed.

title: Importance of Sleep for Health
content: Sleep is the best insurance policy for lifespan and healthspan. It is a life support system and perhaps Mother Nature’s best effort yet at immortality. Sleep acts like a superordinate node in the biological equation of health. If you optimize sleep, you’re doing as much as probably you can from the health regard standpoint in terms of increasing your insurance for a longer life.

title: Latest Insights on Alzheimer’s Disease, Cancer, Exercise, Nutrition, and Fasting
content: A scientist with expertise in the areas of aging, cancer, and nutrition who translates complex scientific topics into actionable insights. Provides her latest thinking as it relates to Alzheimer's.

title: Clinical Trials and Drug Pipeline
content: The current landscape of clinical trials, the drug pipeline, and a promising monoclonal antibody directed at amyloid beta that has the potential to be a disease-modifying drug are discussed.

title: Omicron Variant and Hospitalization
content: South African doctors observed that people were in the hospital about two days instead of eight days, and they proclaimed to the world this is a mild infection. According to the most recent CDC numbers, 98.3% of new cases of COVID in the United States are Omicron. People who are still in the hospital are those who came in with Delta. Unvaccinated people who got Delta. Hospitals are truly strained, but it’s really those who had Delta.

title: COVID-19: Current state of affairs, Omicron, and a search for the end game
content: Discussion about the omicron variant, the risks and benefits of vaccines for all age groups, and the taboo subject of natural immunity and the protection it offers against infection and severe disease. The poor messaging coming from our public officials, the justification (and lack thereof) for certain mandates and policies in light of the current evidence, and the problems caused by the highly politicized and polarized nature of the subject. Themes throughout the conversation include the difference between science and advocacy, the messaging which is sowing mistrust in science despite major progress, and a search for what a possible “end” to this situation might look like.

title: Photosynthesis and Climate Change
content: There are a lot of ways to fix climate change, but the quickest, fastest, and most effective and scalable way is using an ancient carbon capture technology . . . is free. It’s called photosynthesis. It’s basically sun and carbon dioxide in the air. We can solve a lot of the global issues that we have.

title: Insights on Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, exercise, nutrition, and fasting
content: Scientist with expertise in the areas of aging, cancer, and nutrition who translates complex scientific topics into actionable insights. Provides latest thinking as it relates to Alzheimer's.

title: Sleep and Covid-19
content: Sleep has a role in immune function. Good sleep hygiene is important, especially during the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: COVID-19 and Polarization
content: The topic of COVID has become polarized. There are camps for natural immunity versus vaccine immunity. Omicron is a highly transmissible respiratory variant that cannot be eradicated but can be controlled. The shame of getting a pathogen is being destigmatized.

title: Natural immunity from COVID after infection
content: Discussion about natural immunity from COVID after infection.

title: Evacuation of Farm Animals Due to Volcano Eruption
content: In 2018, there was a large volcano eruption on Kīlauea on The Big Island. The lava flow was ~500 yards wide moving at 50 miles an hour. It ended up completely destroying an entire community. In the process, two lava flows formed and they cut off a huge portion of a ranching area, including homes and a bunch of things. The ranchers were already losing much of their land and homes to the lava flows, and now much of their livestock were trapped. Jake and his team developed a net to capture and lift out live cattle via helicopter.

title: Funding
content: The research has been funded extensively by the National Institute of Health (NIH).

title: Fasting, Gut Health, and Sleep
content: Fasting, gut health, blue light, caffeine, REM sleep, and more

title: Healthcare in Nuba Mountains
content: The Nuba Mountains are a remote location where healthcare is a challenge. The hospital in the region has 435 beds and is always at 100% occupancy. At the peak of war, it would be 550 people there, just laying all over the ground. The hospital sees about 300 patients per day. The biggest problem is the logistics of getting the supplies. Supplies have to come from Nairobi which is 2 countries away. It takes weeks to get to Yida, South Sudan. Then its 6 hours dirt roads to get from Yida to Nuba. The hospital tries to make it one full year on that supply that gets sent in.

title: Sleep, Aging and Immune System
content: Sleep gets worse as we age, and therefore our immune system gets worse. One of the most dramatic changes with age, and the most sizable and robust physiological changes with age that we see, is that your sleep gets worse. And sleep is probably one of the most powerful regulators of your immune system. A lack of sleep bends curve of lifespan very dramatically.

title: Looking back at past pandemics for perspective and the potential for another pandemic in the future
content: Discussion about looking back at past pandemics for perspective and the potential for another pandemic in the future.

title: Toe Yoga
content: Toe yoga helps regain and maintain capacity to use the toes. This involves spreading the toes apart and moving the big toe and other toes up and down independently of each other, all while keeping the rest of the foot relatively still.
